author: mynamesyow19
comment:
^ REPUBLICANS forced an end to this program. Let's be clear and give credit where credit is due. 


2022: Then the pandemic hit. In 2020, the government took several extraordinary measures to keep Americans financially afloat, from stimulus checks to enhanced unemployment benefits. Included in that were waivers making school lunch free for every K-12 student.

The waivers meant that kids weren't going into school lunch debt, or dealing with the shame of being on free or reduced-price lunch â€” and that lunch providers could expand what food they were offering to their students.

But Republicans are blocking the renewal of the waivers, spelling a potential end for the program on June 30.

https://www.businessinsider.com/free-school-lunches-in-america-republicans-will-end-2022-6

https://www.foxnews.com/politics/15-gop-governors-urge-biden-admin-stop-using-school-lunch-program-push-radical-agenda-girls-sports

>But Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell is blocking the extension of the waivers, according to a source familiar with the negotiations. So the provision is not in the spending package, as of now.

>Asked about the extension, a GOP leadership aide said that the waivers initially were designated as â€œtemporaryâ€ Covid-19 measures and that the Biden administration did not include the extension in its most recent $22.5 billion request for coronavirus-related assistance. Also, many of the waivers are designed to assist when schools are forced to close, which is no longer a focus.

author: cheysuli
comment:
Posting the story, because this shitty "journalist" never mentions it was **Republicans** that killed it, and they don't deserve the clicks:

>AsÂ schools around the country reopen after winter break, their students are beingÂ reminded of theÂ lunch debt they've racked upÂ this school yearÂ â€“ an uglyÂ reality that follows the endÂ of federalÂ assistance that paid for school meals for more than 50 million students during the pandemic.Â 
Congress ended the free-lunch-for-all program in June, reverting to a system in which low-income families had toÂ fillÂ out paperwork to qualify forÂ aid based on their income. But some families have been left behind because they do notÂ understand the application process, and others are rejected because they do not qualify. A family of four must earn about $36,000 a year or less to qualify for free lunch.Â 

>Schools often feed these students, requiring them to pay later and creating a debt many families cannot pay down.Â For some children, the debt can get so big thatÂ schools stop giving them a full meal.Â 
Community organizations, social media influencers and national nonprofits are trying to help fill the void with donationsÂ to cover the more than $19 millionÂ in debt students have accrued just halfway into the school year.Â 
It doesnâ€™t seem to be enough: Plenty ofÂ kids face going without school lunchesÂ or getting smaller, alternative school mealsÂ when they return to school this winter because of theirÂ negative balances.Â This is happening at a time of historic inflation, whenÂ school meal prices are risingÂ and many families areÂ strugglingÂ to pay rent andÂ feed their children.Â 

>Results fromÂ a national survey by the School Nutrition Association, published Wednesday, shows 847Â schools hadÂ amassedÂ $19.2 million in lunch debt.
Debt variesÂ across the country. Across North Carolina, lunch debt exceeded $1 million as of Nov. 1. OneÂ Wisconsin school district surpassedÂ $14,000 in school lunch debt by October. And in Georgia, aÂ nonprofit called All For Lunch paid $130,000 to wipe the debt of several schools across several metro area counties in December.Â 

>Why does it matter?
>Universal school meals can promote academic achievement,Â keep kids healthier and reduce "lunch shaming" of students who have unpaid meal debt and can't afford their lunch, said Diane Pratt-Heavner, a spokeswoman for the national School Nutrition Association.Â 
According to the national campaign No Kid Hungry, run by the nonprofit Share Our Strength, "students who eat school breakfast have been shown to achieve 17.5% higher scores on standardized math tests and attend 1.5 more days of school per year"Â on average.Â 

>Who is trying to help?
>Several community groups and evenÂ social media influencers are donating to help schools cover students' debtÂ and supportingÂ initiativesÂ that could lead to policy change.
The nonprofitÂ Tusk Philanthropies' Solving Hunger is funding four organizationsÂ focused on promoting policy change related to universal freeÂ healthy school meals. The organization is funding campaigns inÂ Connecticut,Â New York, North CarolinaÂ and Vermont.
In another,Â Sarah Stusek recorded herself callingÂ Mount Vernon Community SchoolÂ in a viral TikTok videoÂ to pay off the Virginia schoolâ€™s nearly $1,700 lunch debt.Â 

>â€œItâ€™s wonderful (Sarah) is doing that, and that so many community organizations have stepped up to help address this," theÂ School Nutrition Association'sÂ Pratt-Heavner said. "But itâ€™sÂ unfortunatelyÂ a short-term solution and one of the reasons Congress should provide school lunches.â€
In recent years,Â newÂ state legislationÂ has emerged to ban lunch-shaming â€“ preventing schools from feeding kids who can't pay or have with debt smaller alternative meals, thereby broadcasting that they haven't paid up.

>Which states offer free mealsÂ to kids?

>Some states opted to continue free-lunch-for-all programs, including Massachusetts, Nevada, Vermont and Pennsylvania.
California,Â MaineÂ and nowÂ Colorado areÂ the only states with laws ensuring permanent universal meal programs for all children, regardless of parents' income.Â 
A few districts, including in ChicagoÂ andÂ New York City, also offer free meals to kids.Â 
Kids are accruing debt in part because schools are having a hard time getting kids to sign up for the federal free and reduced-price school lunch program. Some children don't qualifyÂ but still can't afford meals.
AÂ survey by the National Center for Education StatisticsÂ shows student participation in school meal programs is down from last school year by 23% nationally. The largest drop is in the Midwest at 31%.
The October survey shows that of the 88%Â of schools that operate USDA school lunch and breakfast meal programs, 1 in 4 reported "it was much more or a little more difficult for their school to operate meal programs" this school yearÂ compared withÂ last.

>Schools told the School Nutrition AssociationÂ increasing costs,Â staff shortages, menu item shortages, menu items being discontinued and unpaid meal debt are some of their topÂ challenges.Â
